Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was locking up the workshop for the night. It was Sam, my oldest friend, his voice shaky and urgent. His car had broken down on the highway, miles from anywhere, and he needed me to come get him right away. I could hear the panic in his voice, and I knew he wouldn’t have called unless it was serious. But as I glanced around the shop, I remembered the inspection I was supposed to finish tonight. Tomorrow’s job was a big one—structural beams, heavy machinery, and a crew depending on me to make sure everything was safe. If I left now, I’d be skipping the safety checks, risking not just my own well-being but everyone’s on site. My mind raced, torn between the responsibility I owed my friend and the duty I had as a carpenter. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, and I stood frozen, keys in hand, heart pounding, unable to move in either direction.
